columns.text: In this problem, we will do a cost analysis to determine whether an asset in the firm should be replaced with a newer model.

For the old car:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\$2.65\times\dfrac{12,000}{25}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,272
\end{aligned}$$

The annual cost for the old car is $\$1,272$

For the old truck:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\$2.65\times\dfrac{12,000}{10}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,180
\end{aligned}$$

The annual cost for the old truck is $\$3,180$

For the new car:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\$2.65\times\dfrac{12,000}{40}\\[15 pt]
&=\$795
\end{aligned}$$

The annual cost for the new car is $\$795$

For the new truck:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\$2.65\times\dfrac{12,000}{12.5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,544
\end{aligned}$$

The annual cost for the new car is $\$2,544$

Now we will compare the costs of the new and old models. To determine whether a change is needed, we will subtract the costs of the old model by the cost of the new model.

For the car:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference}&=\$1,272-\$795\\[15 pt]
&=\$477
\end{aligned}$$

If the car is replaced, the difference in costs is $\$477$

For the truck:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference}&=\$3,180-\$2,544\\[15 pt]
&=\$636
\end{aligned}$$

If the truck is replaced, the difference in costs is $\$636$
Based on the data above, since the difference is positive, then it means that the firm will benefit if the two vehicles are upgraded to the newer model.
